title: Description: 3 different way to implement an iterator in Go: callbacks, channels, struct with Next() function.

inline_content.Text: Description: 3 different way to implement an iterator in Go: callbacks, channels, struct with Next() function.

title: Iteration is a frequent need, be it iterating over lines of a file, results or of
SELECT
c
SQL query or files in a directory.

c

title: Before discussing different ways of designing iteration API, let’s see how we would iterate without encapsulating iteration logic.

title: This is intentionally the simplest possible iterator so that we can focus on the implementation of the iterator API and not generating the values to iterate over.

title: This is fine if iteration logic is simple. If our iteration was complex, like iterating over lines in a file, every time we needed to do different processing of the lines, we would end up copy & pasteing a lot of code.

inline_content.Text: This is fine if iteration logic is simple. If our iteration was complex, like iterating over lines in a file, every time we needed to do different processing of the lines, we would end up copy & pasteing a lot of code.

title: For easy reuse we want to encapsulate complex iteration logic and provide simple API to callers.

inline_content.Text: For easy reuse we want to encapsulate complex iteration logic and provide simple API to callers.

title: The caller provides callback function to be called with each value.

inline_content.Text: The caller provides callback function to be called with each value.

error

error
c
from callback stops iteration.

title: Another pattern is to implement iterator struct with 3 functions: *
Next()
c
advances iterator to next value. It returns false to indicate end of iteration (which can be due to error) *
Value()
c
to get the current value of the iterator. The name depends on the kind of value we retrieve * optional
Err()
c
function which returns iteration error

inline_content.Text: Another pattern is to implement iterator struct with 3 functions: *
advances iterator to next value. It returns false to indicate end of iteration (which can be due to error) *
to get the current value of the iterator. The name depends on the kind of value we retrieve * optional

title: Channels and goroutines are Go’s banner features and can be used as iterators.

inline_content.Text: Channels and goroutines are Go’s banner features and can be used as iterators.

title: generateEvenNumbers()
c
returns a channel which will be closed to indicate end of iteration. Closing the channel ends
for
c
loop.

title: If there is no possibility of failing we can send just values over the channel.

inline_content.Text: If there is no possibility of failing we can send just values over the channel.

title: In our case a failure is possiblity, so we have to send a struct that packages the value and possible error:

title: We could use buffered channel, e.g.:
ch := make(chan IntWithError, 128)
c
. That would speed up things if both generation and processing are time consuming by parallelizing those 2 processes.

inline_content.Text: We could use buffered channel, e.g.:
. That would speed up things if both generation and processing are time consuming by parallelizing those 2 processes.

title: In the above example the client doesn’t have a way to stop the channel-based iterator.

inline_content.Text: In the above example the client doesn’t have a way to stop the channel-based iterator.

title: If it just stops processing values from the channel before it’s closed, the generator goroutine will be forever blocked trying to send on a channel no-one is reading from. The goroutine will leak.

inline_content.Text: If it just stops processing values from the channel before it’s closed, the generator goroutine will be forever blocked trying to send on a channel no-one is reading from. The goroutine will leak.

title: We can add ability to stop a channel iterator by using
context
c
created with
context.WithCancel
c

inline_content.Text: We can add ability to stop a channel iterator by using

cancel()
c
on the context we get from
context.WithCancel()
c
or else it’ll leak

inline_content.Text: on the context we get from

title: cancel()
c
asks for the generator to stop but cannot guarantee it. After cancelling we’ll get more values queued on the channel

inline_content.Text: asks for the generator to stop but cannot guarantee it. After cancelling we’ll get more values queued on the channel

title: It’s important to fully drain the channel or else we’ll leak the goroutine that is trying to write to it. In this example we skip processing after reaching stop value.

inline_content.Text: It’s important to fully drain the channel or else we’ll leak the goroutine that is trying to write to it. In this example we skip processing after reaching stop value.

title: Alternatively, we could break the processing loop and then have a loop just to drain the channel:

inline_content.Text: The one that best fits your scenario.

title: The callback pattern makes for a simple implementation of the iterator but callbacks in Go have akward syntax.

inline_content.Text: The callback pattern makes for a simple implementation of the iterator but callbacks in Go have akward syntax.

title: Using
Next()
c
is the hardest to implement but presents nice interface to the caller. It’s most commonly used in Go standard library for complex iterators.

inline_content.Text: is the hardest to implement but presents nice interface to the caller. It’s most commonly used in Go standard library for complex iterators.

title: Channel-based iterator is easy to implent and use by the caller but most expensive. Only in exceptional circumstances the cost should be of concern.

inline_content.Text: Channel-based iterator is easy to implent and use by the caller but most expensive. Only in exceptional circumstances the cost should be of concern.

title: It’s also the only one that is concurrent by nature.

inline_content.Text: It’s also the only one that is concurrent by nature.

title: At the same time, channels are heavy machinery. Don’t over-use them, don’t use channels for things that can be done without them.

inline_content.Text: At the same time, channels are heavy machinery. Don’t over-use them, don’t use channels for things that can be done without them.

title: Channels are meant to serve as a coordination mechanism between goroutines. If you don’t need to launch a goroutine, then you probably don’t need to use channels.

inline_content.Text: Channels are meant to serve as a coordination mechanism between goroutines. If you don’t need to launch a goroutine, then you probably don’t need to use channels.
